conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a region where the light is not directly visible.
The size and position of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
The light source is initially positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The shadows are elongated in the direction away from the light source.
When the light source moves backward, it increases the distance between the light source and the objects.
This change affects both the position and the size of the shadows.
As the light source moves backward, the angle at which the light rays hit the objects changes.
The shadows will shift closer to the objects because the light rays are now coming from a more distant point.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects.
The size of the shadows is determined by the angle of the light rays and the distance from the light source to the objects.
When the light source moves backward, the angle of the light rays becomes less steep.
This results in the shadows becoming smaller because the light rays are more parallel to the ground, reducing the spread of the shadow.
When the light source moves backward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will both move closer to the objects and become smaller.
